title: Introduction to melbWeather
text: vignette introduces melbWeather package, provides tools analyzing visualizing Melbourne’s weather data.

title: Introduction to melbWeather
text: Welcome melbWeather package! package designed help analyze visualize historical weather data Melbourne, Australia. provides functions exploring temperature trends, weather summaries, visualizations using daily minimum maximum temperatures. melbWeather package comes built-dataset called weather_data includes daily weather records Melbourne.

title: Introduction to melbWeather
text: install melbWeather package, use following command R console:
code: # Install the `remotes` package if you haven't already install.packages("remotes")  # Install the `melbWeather` package from GitHub remotes::install_github("ETC5523-2024/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-tdew0002")

title: Introduction to melbWeather
text: package installed, load :

title: Introduction to melbWeather
text: vignette introduces melbWeather package, provides tools analyzing visualizing Melbourne’s weather data.

title: Introduction to melbWeather
text: Use functions melbWeather package explore temperature trends:
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(weather_data, aes(x = date, y = minimum_temperature_degree_c)) +   geom_line() +   labs(title = "Minimum Temperatures in Melbourne")

title: Introduction to melbWeather
text: melbWeather package also includes interactive Shiny app exploring weather data. launch Shiny app, use following function: Shiny app provides interactive controls filter data date range temperature type, making easy visualize trends explore dataset detail.

title: Interactive Shiny App
text: Experience features melbWeather package interactive Shiny app .

title: melbWeather
text: pkgdown site. melbWeather package provides tools analyze visualize Melbourne’s weather data, including minimum maximum temperature trends time. designed students analysts looking explore temperature patterns user-friendly way using R Shiny.

title: melbWeather
text: can install development version melbWeather GitHub : GitHub :
code: # Install the 'remotes' package if you haven't already install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("ETC5523-2024/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-tdew0002")

title: melbWeather
text: Load package :

title: melbWeather
text: clean_weather_data() function created used clean raw weather data files performing analysis. ’s example use : clean_weather_data() function combines data files, standardises column names, formats dates analysis.
code: # Assuming you have raw CSV files for minimum and maximum temperatures min_temp_path <- "data-raw/melbourne_weather_min.csv" max_temp_path <- "data-raw/melbourne_weather_max.csv"  # Clean the data using the clean_weather_data function weather_data <- clean_weather_data(min_temp_path, max_temp_path)  # View the first few rows of the cleaned data head(weather_data)

title: melbWeather
text: User need use clean_weather_data() function, instead dataset created clean_weather_data() function package can directly access using weather_data, contains daily weather records Melbourne, including minimum maximum temperatures.
code: # Load Melbourne weather data data("weather_data")  # Display the first few rows of the data head(weather_data) #>   year month day minimum_temperature_degree_c maximum_temperature_degree_c #> 1 2013    01  01                           NA                           NA #> 2 2013    01  02                           NA                           NA #> 3 2013    01  03                           NA                           NA #> 4 2013    01  04                           NA                           NA #> 5 2013    01  05                           NA                           NA #> 6 2013    01  06                           NA                           NA

title: melbWeather
text: example summarising basic dataset: can also embed plots, example:
code: summary(weather_data$minimum_temperature_degree_c) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's  #>    0.60    8.60   11.30   11.57   14.50   28.00     152 library(ggplot2) ggplot(weather_data, aes(x = as.Date(paste(year, month, day, sep = "-")), y = minimum_temperature_degree_c)) +   geom_line(color = "#005b96") +   labs(     title = "Minimum Temperature Trend in Melbourne",     x = "Date",     y = "Temperature (°C)"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: melbWeather
text: Package Introduction: Provides brief overview melbWeather package . Installation: Includes instructions installing package using remotes. Getting Started: Shows load package access main dataset. Example Analysis: Demonstrates simple plotting example using ggplot2 weather_data dataset. Shiny App: Explains launch Shiny app locally provides link online version hosted shinyapps.io. Documentation Vignettes: Directs users pkgdown site full documentation tutorials. License Acknowledgements: Mentions license credits data source.

title: Clean Melbourne Weather Data — clean_weather_data
text: Merges cleans Melbourne weather data minimum maximum temperature files.

title: Clean Melbourne Weather Data — clean_weather_data
text: min_data_path path minimum temperature CSV file. max_data_path path maximum temperature CSV file.

title: Clean Melbourne Weather Data — clean_weather_data
text: cleaned data frame columns: year, month, day, minimum_temperature_degree_c, maximum_temperature_degree_c.

what: Launch the Melbourne Temperature Shiny App — startApp
title: Launch the Melbourne Temperature Shiny App — startApp
text: function launches Shiny app exploring Melbourne temperature data.

title: Launch the Melbourne Temperature Shiny App — startApp
Melbourne Weather Data — weather_data
text: dataset containing daily minimum maximum temperatures Melbourne 2013 2024.

title: Melbourne Weather Data — weather_data
text: data frame columns: year Year observation (integer). month Month observation (integer). day Day observation (integer). minimum_temperature_degree_c Minimum temperature degrees Celsius (numeric). maximum_temperature_degree_c Maximum temperature degrees Celsius (numeric).

title: Melbourne Weather Data — weather_data
text: Bureau Meteorology, Australia
